title: Great British Bake Off's Rosie praises crew for managing nut allergy
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

The Great British Bake Off contestant Rosie Brandreth-Poynter has thanked the Channel 4 show’s crew for managing her nut allergy.

The veterinary surgeon, who was eliminated from the competition last night after a testing Patisserie Week, revealed that the series employed a ‘nut runner’ to keep her from having an allergic reaction.

Rosie praised the lengths the production team went to in a heartwarming letter she penned after the episode, writing: ‘The crew were incredible – they managed my nut allergy so well and kept everything safe – including the awesome NUT RUNNER – how many people can put that on a CV?’

She added on Twitter: ‘They kept all my equipment totally separate and cleaned my bench separately.’

Rosie was eliminated during last night’s semi-final (Picture: Channel 4)

In another message shared on the Bake Off website, Rosie continued: ‘I have a nut allergy so I was so amazed that the production team took that on board, had me in the tent and had to adapt certain practices for filming, everyone worked around it so well, the backroom production team were incredible and flexible.’

Rosie penned a heartwarming letter (Picture: Twitter)

Rosie sadly exited the series one week before the final, meaning that David Atherton, Steph Blackwell and Alice Fevronia will be competiting for the highly-coveted cake plate trophy.

Upon leaving the show, she said: ‘I am gutted. I just have to be happy with everything that I’ve done so far.’

‘I have no idea what will happen for me next,’ Rosie added in her letter. ‘In the meantime I am a full-time vet and I love my job, caring for animals, which is very rewarding.

‘And I will continue baking and hopefully make more time for it in the future, who knows what will happen?’

The Great British Bake Off final airs Tuesday at 8pm on Channel 4.
